docs.lead_paragraph: OPEC Decides to Maintain Production Levels for Now The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries decided to hold to its current production level of 23.2 million barrels a day. The decision was expected, despite falling prices. Yet OPEC, a cartel that produces about 40 percent of the world's oil, appeared to leave open the option of cutting production before its next meeting in November if prices continued to tumble. [Page C2.]

docs.lead_paragraph: The number of Americans without health insurance declined last year for the second year in a row, after rising steadily for more than a decade, the Census Bureau said today. The bureau found a significant increase in the number of people with coverage provided by employers, and it reported a substantial increase in the number of children with insurance.

headline.main: Number of Uninsured Drops for 2nd Year

docs.abstract: Census Bureau reports that number of Americans without health insurance declined last year for second year in row, after rising steadily for more than decade; 38.7 million people were uninsured, or 14 percent of population, as compared to 14.3 percent in 1999; number of uninsured childred dropped to 8.5 million; several experts say downward trend is unlikely to continue; chart of uninsured population by age, race and ethnicity (M)
docs.snippet: The number of Americans without health insurance declined last year for the second year in a row, after rising steadily for more than a decade, the Census Bureau said today.    The bureau found a significant increase in the number of people with...

docs.lead_paragraph: The Health and Human Services Department said yesterday that Electronic Data Systems, Oracle and PricewaterhouseCoopers had won a contract to create a new accounting system for Medicare and Medicaid. The potential value of the contract is about $328 million, the agency said. PricewaterhouseCoopers will integrate systems, Oracle will provide accounting software, and Electronic Data will oversee the Internet applications. Medicare, the health insurance program for the elderly and disabled, has 53 different accounting programs used by private insurance companies to process and pay nearly three million Medicare claims each day. The new project will replace those programs and mainframe computers with a Web-based system.

headline.main: THREE COMPANIES WIN SYSTEM CONTRACT FOR MEDICARE

docs.abstract: Health and Human Services Department awards Electronic Data Systems, Oracle Corp and PricewaterhouseCoopers a contract to create new accounting system for Medicare and Medicaid; potential value of contract is about $328 million (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill said today that the federal government would help states shore up their unemployment insurance programs to cope with the surge in layoffs after the terrorist attacks and might also extend benefits to jobless workers for a longer period. Mr. O'Neill spoke a few hours after the Labor Department reported that new claims for unemployment benefits rose last week to their highest level in more than nine years. The increase, to 450,000 from 392,000 the week before, was among the clearest indicators of how the aftershocks from the attacks are rippling through the economy.

headline.main: U.S. Will Help States With Unemployment Insurance

docs.abstract: Treasury Sec Paul H O'Neill says federal government will help states shore up their unemployment insurance programs to cope with surge in layoffs after terrorist attacks and might also extend benefits to jobless workers for longer period; is not yet satisfied New York State has enough funds; says Bush administration continues to review wide variety of options for helping economy, including tax cuts that would be directed at individuals and businesses; says that debate within administration is shifting from whether government should pass economic stimulus package to what types of actions it should take and that Pres Bush is likely to settle on specific package soon; graph; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-12 During a Yearlong Intifada, Fear Has Gripped Mideast Among the facts upon which Israelis and Palestinians disagree is what day the intifada began. Palestinians say Sept. 28, 2000, when Ariel Sharon, now the Israeli prime minister, visited a site sacred to Muslims; Israelis tend to say the day before or the day after. But people on both sides describe similar effects of the events since: fear and desperation. A3 Shooting Rampage in Swiss Hall A 57-year-old gunman stormed into a crowded regional legislature in Zug, killing 14 people and detonating a hand grenade before shooting himself dead. It was the bloodiest episode in the normally tranquil country's recent criminal history and prompted talk of tightening Switzerland's relaxed security. A6

docs.lead_paragraph: Higher hospital bills and rising prices for prescription drugs drove last year's large jump in health-care costs, according to a private analysis released today. At the same time, the premiums that people paid to carry health insurance were going up even faster than the cost of health care, according to the report, which was released by the Center for Studying Health System Change. The center attributed the rise to the desire of insurance companies to increase profits after several lean years.

headline.main: Jump in Health Care Costs Is Analyzed

docs.abstract: Center for Studying Health System Change reports that cost of health care grew 7.2 percent in 2000, driven by higher hospital bills and rising prices for prescription drugs (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Lloyd's of London, the world's biggest insurance market, said today that it expected to face £1.3 billion in claims ($1.92 billion) related to the terrorist attacks on the United States, making it the most costly single calamity in Lloyd's 320-year history. The claims will ''put severe pressure on many of the weaker operating units'' within the Lloyd's market of 108 syndicates, according to a statement by Moody's Investor Services. The syndicates variously compete and cooperate with one another to write mainly specialist aviation, property and other insurance contracts.

headline.main: Lloyd's Expects Claims From Attacks to Top $1.9 Billion

docs.abstract: Lloyd's of London expects to face 1.3 billion pounds in claims ($1.92 billion) related to terrorist attacks on US, making it most costly single calamity in Lloyd's 320-year history; says its asset base of $27 billion can take strain (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: DIPLOMATIC and military efforts may rightly take precedence, but the White House has provided minimal economic leadership since the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon. What action has been taken, notably the aid to airlines, has been more a reaction to a clear-cut emergency than part of a coordinated plan. The lack of a strong public voice on the economy has contributed substantially to the sense in America that the economic center is not holding and is itself feeding the recessionary fires. President Bush's first speech on the economy was inexplicably relegated to a radio address last Saturday, 11 days after the attack.

headline.main: Economic Scene; In responding to terrorism, the administration is falling short on the economic front.

docs.abstract: Jeff Madrick Economic Scene column holds Bush administration has provided minimal economic leadership since terrorist attacks; says what action has been taken, notably aid to airlines, has been more reaction to clear-cut emergency than part of coordinated plan; contends lack of strong public voice on economy has contributed substantially to sense in America that economic center is not holding and is itself feeding recessionary fires; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Fernando Ferrer and Mark Green began New York's first mayoral runoff contest since 1977 yesterday by beginning to carve up the support of the two candidates they vanquished in Tuesday's Democratic primary. Mr. Ferrer, the Bronx borough president, pulled off what was perhaps the biggest surprise of the day, winning the endorsement of one of the losing candidates, Peter F. Vallone, the City Council speaker. ''He will bring people together and give them the opportunity to be what they want to be,'' Mr. Vallone said of Mr. Ferrer during an early afternoon news conference in Queens.

headline.main: Ferrer and Green Divide The Spoils of Their Rivals
headline.kicker: THE NEW YORK PRIMARY: THE DEMOCRATS

docs.abstract: Fernando Ferrer and Mark Green begin New York's first mayoral runoff contest since 1977 by beginning to carve up support of two candidates they vanquished in Tuesday's Democratic primary; Ferrer receives endorsement from Peter Vallone while Green receives support from Democratic leaders of Brooklyn and Queens, backers of Alan Hevesi (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: AT 34, Christopher Michel sounds like an old geezer. A Navy navigator and mission commander in the early 1990's, he calls himself ''a representative of the old school, the old generation.'' In Saudi Arabia during the Persian Gulf war a decade ago, ''one of the neat things being over there was writing 'Free Desert Storm' on the envelope where the stamp goes,'' he said. ''It was all about mail, physical mail. Still is, but today expectations have changed. People expect to hear every day.''

headline.main: Military Families Turn, Gingerly, to the Net

docs.abstract: Internet allows military personnel to stay in close touch with families, but in light of Sept 11 terrorist attacks, security is stepped up; security protocols are added to sites and suggestions are given to family members about how to communicate and type of information they should be wary of transmiting; photo (M)
